answers: GPU [or graphics processing unit; prompt on “video cards”]
parts: Name these devices whose APIs include DirectX and OpenGL. These devices are used to render images and are heavily used in video gaming.

NVIDIA’s GPUs, like the Tesla, use this programming API, which uses C++ syntax rules. Unlike OpenGL and previous APIs, it is designed with general purpose GPU programming in mind, rather than graphics.

PyTorch and several other machine learning libraries that can be implemented on GPUs rely on this data type, which is essentially an N-dimensional array. Google’s machine-learning library has this data type in its name.

answers: physicians [or doctors; accept surgeons or logical equivalents]
parts: Name this sociologist who characterized the sick role as a form of “sanctioned deviance” in his theory of social systems.

Parsons argued that there was an asymmetric distribution of power between patients and these professionals, who act as gatekeepers to the sick role. Michel Foucault described this profession looking at patients with a “medical gaze.”

This sociologist described how disabilities and mental illnesses can act as “deeply discrediting” attributes in his theory of social stigma. This man’s “total institution” model of mental asylums does not allow for the type of sanctioned deviance described by Parsons.
Name this grand duchy held by King William III of the Netherlands which Napoleon III offered to buy in 1867. German nationalist concern for this tiny Benelux state sparked a war scare.

This Saxon foreign minister of Austria proposed annexing Luxembourg to Belgium and compensating France with Belgian land. This predecessor to Gyula Andrassy negotiated the 1867 Ausgleich with Hungarian leaders.
The Treaty of London that resolved the crisis stipulated Luxembourgian neutrality and the removal of its Prussian garrison, but allowed it to remain in this pan-German customs union.

answers: Argentina [The author is Jorge Luis Borges.]
parts: Name this home country of Alfonsina Storni. Another author from this country had a bad inspirational poem, “Instants,” wrongly attributed to him, causing critics to draw ironic comparisons to his short story about an “Author of the Quixote.”
This Chilean theoretical physicist is better known for writing many “anti-poems,” often saying “I take back everything I said!” after giving recitations.
This other Chilean poet wrote “I will lower you to the humble and sunny ground” to her lover in “Sonnets of Death.”

answers: Gradus ad Parnassum [by Muzio Clementi; the parody is “Doctor Gradus ad Parnassum” from Children’s Corner]
parts: Name this three-volume collection of 100 instructional pieces for piano. The composer of this collection once fought a piano ‘duel’ with Mozart which was declared a draw.

Clementi’s Sonatina in C major appears in the third volume of the piano curriculum in this teaching method. It is named for the Japanese violinist who compiled the 10-volume curriculum still used to teach violin in this method.

This 20th-century composer’s method of music education relies on learning through play, especially with mallet percussion instruments. He also composed a cantata based on medieval poems by goliards about sex, wine, and fortune.

Name this state, whose governor Jim Folsom commuted the penalty to a life sentence after Department of State pressure. Jim Crow laws in this state’s cities of Birmingham and Montgomery fueled Soviet propaganda.

The phrase “and you are lynching blacks” became a popular retort to U.S. criticism of Soviet human rights after artist Dmitri Moor created a poster about these Alabama boys accused of rape at the center of Powell v. Alabama.
This Emory University School of Law professor cited the case of Jimmy Wilson in Alabama while analyzing the effect of the Cold War on social reform in her book Cold War Civil Rights.
Identify this shrine of Amaterasu containing the Sacred mirror. Saio were members of the royal family who were meant to serve this location which is rebuilt every 20 years.
Buddhism and Shintoism were syncretized following the Heian era resulting in the construction of jingu-ji, where Buddhist monks would venerate these Shinto deities including Susano’o.

Honji suijaki, the theory that Buddhist deities manifested themselves as kami, was first promulgated by the Tendai school founded by Saicho, a friend of Kukai who founded this similarly esoteric Buddhist school.
Name this novel which begins and ends in the middle of a sentence describing a place “a last a loved a long the” “riverrun, past Eve and Adam’s.”
This Irish author traced the dead hod carrier Finnegan through various incarnations of people with the initials HCE in Finnegan’s Wake.

The section “Anna Livia Plurabelle” within Finnegan’s Wake is framed as a dialogue filled with river names between two women performing this action. Those women doing this action gossip about HCE before turning into a tree and a stone.
Name these cytoskeletal structures that are the major component of the mitotic spindle. Kinesin and dynein attach to and move along these structures.
The dynamic instability of microtubules arises from tubulin’s stability as a polymer only when bound to this molecule, which it spontaneously hydrolyzes once polymerized.
During mitosis, this is the name given to microtubules that do not attach to the kinetochore. Instead, they interact with the cell membrane to generate force.

answers: Dialogues des Carmélites [or Dialogues of the Carmelites] (by Francis Poulenc)
parts: Name this opera in which Blanche de la Forge is forced to choose between her life and her religious oath. She chooses the latter after seeing her colleague Sister Constance walk to her death.
The title courtesan joins a convent and is praised as a saint by the nuns in this composer’s opera Thaïs (“ty-eese”), which includes an oft-excerpted “Meditation” for violin and orchestra.
The title nun secretly had an illegitimate child in this composer’s opera Suor Angelica, which forms the middle third of the collection Il trittico. He also composed Madama Butterfly.

Name this “peculiar institution" that the 1619 Project argues underpins most of American society, from capitalism to traffic jams. It began with the arrival of around 20 Africans in Old Point Comfort, Virginia.

The 1619 project was spearheaded by Nikole Hannah-Jones, who discussed the integration of Michael Brown’s school district in a This American Life episode with this title. This phrase also titles a painting of a girl walking past a splattered, smashed tomato.

Jamelle Bouie’s piece for the 1619 Project connects Calhoun-ian nullification to this political movement. In an ethnographic study of this movement, Theda Skocpol and Vanessa Williamson argue it is rooted in racial fears of “where ‘their country’ may be headed,” not economic arguments.

answers: The Wanderers [or Peredvizhniki; or The Itinerants; or The Society for Traveling Exhibitions; or Obshchestvo peredvizhnykh vystavok]
cossacks [or The Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks to Sultan Mehmed IV of the Ottoman Empire]
parts: Name this movement that grew out of a protest of the Imperial Academy’s competition to depict “The Entry of Odin into Valhalla.” It was named for its mobile exhibitions, which mainly featured nationalistic landscapes.
Ilya Repin was a member of the Wanderers who painted the toils of peasants from this country, such as in his Barge Haulers on the Volga.

Just before dying, Repin painted an elaborately dressed member of this group in The Hopak. Repin also depicted a “Reply” of people of this group that shows a raucous group of them laughing while drafting a letter.

answers: Plutonium-239 [or Pu-239; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this reaction in which a nucleus splits apart into two lighter nuclei, which was harnessed for weapons research in the Manhattan Project.
This scientist first observed nuclear fission of uranium with Otto Frisch and Otto Hahn but refused to work on the Manhattan Project. She also first observed the Auger effect in 1922.

Experiments with a 60-inch cyclotron during the Manhattan project led to the discovery of this isotope as an alternative to uranium for fissile weapons. Most breeder reactors produce this isotope by bombarding uranium with fast neutrons.

answers: High King of Ireland [accept Ard-Rí na hÉireann; (“ARD-Ree Nuh HAIR-un”) prompt on king of Ireland]
parts: Identify this position, which the Milesian dynasty ruled over. Conn of the Hundred Battles held this position after the Stone of Destiny was cleaved for not recognizing Lugaid.
This saint helped spread Christianity across Ireland by approaching the High King Laoghaire (“LEE-ruh”) about converting. He may be better known for getting rid of snakes in Ireland.
Members of the Tuatha de Danann were early High Kings of Ireland, where they regularly battled this race of creatures. One of them with one eye named Balor could kill people by looking at them.
This character complains “Must...my projects bend to the iron yoke of a mechanical system?” when considering how to murder his father. He also tries to seduce his brother’s lover Amalia.
Franz Moor and his brother Karl were created by this German author of Wallenstein and William Tell.

The idealistic Karl Moor becomes an arsonist and opposes his rationalist brother Franz in this sturm und drang play. In this work, Karl ties himself to a tree and demand his men turn him in after killing his lover.
Name this city where the youth organization Pora! coordinated protests that unseated Kuchma’s preferred successor Victor Yanukovych following an election accused of massive fraud.

Yanukovych regained the Ukranian presidency in 2010 and proceeded to jail this leader of the Orange Revolution on the grounds she had abused her office as prime minister while signing a gas deal with Russia.

Yanukovych fled the country while Tymoshenko was freed after a 2014 revolution that began in Kiev’s Maidan square after he scrapped a deal associating Ukraine with this European organization headquartered in Brussels.

answers: “The World of Wrestling” or “Le Monde ou l’on catche”
parts: Identify this first essay of the collection Mythologies, which argues that the originality of the title activity derives from the “excesses” that make it “spectacle and not a sport.”

This French post-structuralist philosopher authored the essays in Mythologies and characterized Japan as the titular Empire of Signs. He also wrote the punningly-titled “La mort de l’auteur,” or “The Death of the Author.”
In this other work, Barthes analyzed the structure of Balzac’s novella Sarrasine and theorized five specific “codes” that allow a reader to understand the text.
Name this novel, which focuses on the fourteen-year-old pregnant girl Esch as her family prepares for Hurricane Katrina.
Salvage the Bones was written by this MacArthur genius grant-award winning author of Sing, Unburied, Sing.
Because Esch loves Greek mythology, Salvage the Bones is structured around this anti-heroine from a Euripides play, who kills her children after she is betrayed by Jason.

answers: pyrrolidine [or tetrahydropyrrole; do not accept or prompt on “pyrrole”]
parts: The Hofmann elimination forms the less substituted product. That deviates from this rule, which states that the more substituted alkene will be the major product in an elimination.
Along with Karl Loffler, Hofmann names a ring-forming reaction that primarily forms this five membered heterocycle, which has formula (CH2)4NH (“C-H-2-4-N-H”).
To separate benzene and toluene from coal tar, Hofmann’s student C. B. Mansfield developed a “fractional” form of this technique, which separates components of a mixture by their boiling point.

answers: Bengal [or Bengali; prompt on India; do not accept “Bangladesh”]
Tagore [or Abanindranath Tagore; or Rabindranath Tagore]
parts: Name this Hindu reform movement founded by Raja Ram Mohan Roy which rejected castes and the Vedas in favor of theological unitarianism.
Many followers of Brahmo Samaj championed “[this region’s] Renaissance,” whose other luminaries included the philosopher Swami Vivekananda and the scientist Satyendra Nath Bose.
Many members of this family spearheaded the Bengali Renaissance, including the founder of the Bengal School of Art, Abanindranath, and the Nobel Literature Prize winner Rabindranath.
